column1: Inability to fully extend the joints from birth
Bleeding or spotting from the vagina between periods
Periods that occur less than 28 days apart (more common) or more than 35 days apart
Time between periods changes each month
Bleeding that lasts for more days than normal or for more than 7 days (menstrual)
Spasms of the stomach and intestines
Chest pain, which may increase after eating, or may be felt as pain in the back, neck, and arms
Limited range of motion of the elbows
Spine curvatures called kyphosis and lordosis
Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
Holes in the skin or tissues under the skin
Pustules (small red bumps containing white or yellow pus)
Weakness of the face or facial asymmetry
Heart enlargement, which can cause fainting or shortness of breath
Large feet (change in shoe size), large hands (change in ring or glove size)
Large glands in the skin (sebaceous glands) causing oily skin, thickening of the skin, skin tags (growths)
Unusual and excessive sweating on face or palms
Cough that produces mucus -- the mucus may be clear or yellow-green
Shortness of breath that gets worse with activity
Walking problems (unsteady gait) that can lead to falls
Pain that spreads to your back or below your right shoulder blade
Yellowing of skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)
Pain in the shoulder, arm, neck, jaw, back, or belly area
Discomfort that feels like tightness, squeezing, crushing, burning, choking, or aching
Pain in the arms or legs
Respiratory failure, when muscles involved in breathing become weak
Changes in mental status or mood
Flank pain(between the ribs and hips)
Swelling due to the body keeping in fluid (may be seen in the legs, ankles, and feet)
Urination changes, such as ... excessive urination at night...
Urination changes, such as little or no urine, ... or urination that stops completely
Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs from an enlarged liver or spleen
Pinpoint red spots on the skin
Swollen lymph nodes in the neck, under arms, and groin
Inability to walk in a straight line, or walk at all
Acting defiant or showing impulsive behavior
Crying, feeling sad or hopeless, and possibly withdrawing from other people
Skipped heartbeats and other physical complaints
Changes in muscle tone, especially muscle spasms and uncontrolled movements
Being afraid of spending time alone
places where escape might be hard
Feeling detached or separated from others
Feeling that the body/environment is not real
Having an unusual temper or agitation
No color in the hair, skin, or iris of the eye
Lighter than normal skin and hair
Puffy eyelids, most often in the morning
Widened blood vessels in the clear tissue covering the white of the eye
Hives (especially over the neck and face)
Difficulty performing more than one task at a time
Language problems, such as trouble remembering the names of familiar objects
Losing interest in things previously enjoyed and being in a flat mood
Personality changes and loss of social skills
Change in sleep patterns, often waking up at night
Rectal pain while having a bowel movement (tenesmus)
Abdominal pain, more so in the right, upper part of the abdomen; pain is intense, continuous or stabbing
Difficulty lifting, climbing stairs, and walking
Difficulty swallowing -- choking easily, drooling, or gagging
Head drop due to weakness of the neck muscles
Speech problems, such as a slow or abnormal speech pattern (slurring of words)
A lump in or near the anus
Swollen lymph nodes in the groin or anal region
Lower neck lump, which often grows quickly
Overactive thyroid (symptoms like rapid heart rate, weight loss, anxiety)
Feeling weak or tired more often than usual, or with exercise
Numbness and tingling of hands or feet
Blue color to the whites of the eyes
Desire to eat ice or other non-food things (pica syndrome)
Abnormal or increased menstrual bleeding in females
Light hair, skin, and eye color compared to rest of family
Small head size compared to body, flattened back of head
Excessive movement of the hands and limbs
Walking with arms uplifted and hands waving
Discharge of pus from the rectum
Redness, painful and hardened tissue in the area of the anus
intense fear of gaining weight or becoming fat
Refuses to keep their weight at what is considered normal ...
Has a body image that is very distorted ...
Going to the bathroom right after meals ...
Refusing to eat around other people ...
Using pills to make themselves urinate ...
A popping sound at the time of injury
Obvious knee swelling within 6 hours of injury
Pain, especially when you try to put weight on the injured leg
Difficulty in continuing with your sport
An itchy sore develops that is similar to an insect bite
A scab often forms, and then dries and falls off within 2 weeks
Swelling (edema) in any area of the body, especially in the legs
Too much or too little acid in the blood
Brain damage from low oxygen level
Holes (necrosis) in the skin or tissues underneath
Bruising and bleeding under the skin
Apathy (loss of desire to do anything)
Slowdown or stoppage of the bowels
Dry mucous membranes in the mouth
Eyes move quickly from side to side
good at flattery and manipulating other people's emotions
Disregard the safety of self and others
sharp, stabbing, tearing, or ripping chest pain
Anxiety and a feeling of doom
Waking up short of breath some time after falling asleep
Uneven, rapid, racing, pounding, or fluttering pulse
Early closure of sutures between bones of the skull, noted by ridging along sutures
Fusion or severe webbing of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th fingers, often called mitten hands
Large or late-closing soft spot on a baby's skull
Webbing or fusion of the toes
Rash, small pinpoint red marks on the skin (petechiae)
pain may be worse when you walk, cough, or make sudden movements
Distorted, repeated, or left out speech sounds or words, the person has difficulty putting words together in the correct order
Struggling to pronounce the right word
More difficulty using longer words, either all the time, or sometimes
Ability to use short, everyday phrases or sayings (such as "How are you?") without a problem
Better writing ability than speaking ability
Irregular, uneven, possibly with extra or skipped heart beats
Decreased or no pulse in an arm or leg
Lack of movement in the arm or leg
Pale color of the arm or leg (pallor)
Weakness of an arm or leg
Reduced ability to move the joint
Redness and warmth of the skin around a joint
Worms leaving the body through the nose or mouth
Coughing up foul-smelling, greenish or dark phlegm (sputum), or phlegm that contains pus or blood
Seeing food or tube feed material (if being fed artificially) in your sputum
Cough with or without sputum (phlegm) production
Pulling in of the skin between the ribs when breathing (intercostal retractions)
Abnormal breathing pattern (breathing out takes more than twice as long as breathing in)
Bluish color to the lips and face (cyanosis)
Decreased coordination of movements (ataxia) in late childhood that can include ataxic gait (cerebellar ataxia), jerky gait, unsteadiness
Discoloration of skin areas exposed to sunlight
Enlarged blood vessels in skin of nose, ears, and inside of the elbow and knee
Enlarged blood vessels in the whites of the eyes
Jerky or abnormal eye movements (nystagmus) late in the disease
Severe respiratory infections that keep coming back (recurring)
Dry skin all over the body, or areas of bumpy skin on the back of the arms and front of the thighs
Raw areas of the skin from scratching
Skin color changes, such as more or less color than the normal skin tone
Thickened or leather-like areas, which can occur after long-term irritation and scratching
Symptoms due to embolism of tumor material
Bluish skin, especially on the fingers (Raynaud phenomenon)
Curvature of nails accompanied by soft tissue swelling (clubbing) of the fingers
Fingers that change color upon pressure or with cold or stress
Doesn't pay attention to details or makes careless mistakes
Has problems focusing during tasks or play
Doesn't listen when spoken to directly
Doesn't follow through on instructions and doesn't finish schoolwork or chores
Has problems organizing tasks and activities
Avoids or doesn't like tasks that require mental effort
Leaves their seat when they should stay in their seat
Runs about or climbs when they shouldn't be doing so
Has problems playing or working quietly
Is often on the go, acts as if "driven by a motor"
Blurts out answers before questions have been completed
Be very sensitive to sight, hearing, touch, smell, or taste
Be very upset when routines are changed
Repeat body movements over and over
Can't start or maintain a conversation
Develops language slowly or not at all
Doesn't adjust gaze to look at objects that others are looking at
Doesn't refer to self the right way
Doesn't point to show other people objects
Repeats words or memorized passages, such as commercials
May not respond to eye contact or smiles, or may avoid eye contact
Prefers to be alone rather than with others
Has very high or very low senses of sight, hearing, touch, smell, or taste
May find normal noises painful and hold their hands over their ears
May withdraw from physical contact because it's too stimulating or overwhelming
Rubs surfaces, mouths or licks objects
May have a very high or very low response to pain
Doesn't imitate the actions of others
Shows little pretend or imaginative play
Gets stuck on a single topic or task
Is aggressive toward others or self
Shows a strong need for things being the same
Goosebumps, flushed (red) skin above the level of the spinal cord injury
Irregular heartbeat, slow or fast pulse
Feeling full after only a few bites
Blood pressure drop with position that causes dizziness when standing
easily hurt when people criticize or disapprove of them
Hold back too much in intimate relationships
reluctant to become involved with people
Avoid activities or jobs that involve contact with others
Be shy in social situations out of fear of doing something wrong
Make potential difficulties seem worse than they are
Hold the view they are not good socially, not as good as other people, or unappealing
Other rashes on the head of the penis
A tender lump on either side of the vaginal opening
Rate of weight gain is much lower than that of other children of similar age and sex
Movement changes, such as involuntary or slowed movements
Uncontrollable, repeated movements, speech, or cries (tics)
Poor muscle coordination that usually develops after age 10
Stool abnormalities, including fatty stools that appear pale in color, frothy stools, and abnormally foul-smelling stools
Difficulty walking that gets worse over time; by age 25 to 30, the person is usually unable to walk
Difficulty getting up from the floor and climbing stairs
Difficulty with running, hopping, and jumping
Muscle weakness in the arms, neck, and other areas is not as severe as in the lower body
Red birth mark on forehead or eyelids (nevus flammeus)
Overgrowth of one side of the body (hemihyperplasia/hemihypertrophy)
Tumor growth, such as Wilms tumors and hepatoblastomas
Difficulty eating and drinking because food falls out of one side of the mouth
Drooling due to lack of control over the muscles of the face
Drooping of the face, such as the eyelid or corner of the mouth
Problems smiling, grimacing, or making facial expressions
Dry eye, which may lead to eye sores or infections
Headache if there is an infection such as Lyme disease
Sound that is louder in one ear (hyperacusis)
Feeling like you are spinning or moving
Feeling like the world is spinning around you
Vision problems, such as a feeling that things are jumping or moving
Loss of feeling (sensation) in hands and feet
Loss of muscle function or paralysis of the lower legs
Awakening at night short of breath
Abdominal pain in the upper right side
Eats large amounts of food in a short period
Is not able to control overeating
Eats food very fast each time
Keeps eating even when full (gorging) or until uncomfortably full
Feels guilty, disgusted, ashamed, or depressed after eating so much
Lack of self-control and reckless behavior
Very irritable mood, racing thoughts, talking a lot, and false beliefs about self or abilities
Concerns about things that are not true (delusions)
Continuous feeling of a full bladder
Waking up at night to urinate (nocturia)
Inability to urinate except in certain positions
Signs of UTI (such as fever, pain when urinating, and need to urinate often)
Impulsiveness, such as with substance use or sexual relationships
Self-injury, such as wrist cutting or overdosing
Changes in mental status, such as confusion, slow response or thinking, unable to focus, or sleepiness
Decreased ability to feel touch or pain (sensation)
Loss of muscle function, typically on one side
Wide (dilated) pupils and no movement in one or both eyes
Small pits, lumps, or skin tags at either side of the neck or just below the jawbone
Fluid drainage from a pit on the neck
Breast lump or lump in the armpit that is hard, has uneven edges, and usually does not hurt
Change in the size, shape, or feel of the breast or nipple
Fluid from the nipple, fluid may be bloody, clear to yellow, green, or look like pus
Muscles around the ribs sink in as the child tries to breathe in (called intercostal retractions)
Infant's nostrils get wide when breathing
Reddish or purplish color in a circle around spider bite
Large sore (ulcer) in the area of the bite
Red, thickened skin along the inside edge at the base of the big toe
A bony bump at the first toe joint, with decreased movement in the toe site
Pain over the joint, which pressure from shoes makes worse
Big toe turned outward toward the other toes and may cross over the second toe, as a result, corns and calluses often develop where the first and second toes overlap
Abnormal posture with flexed arms and straight legs
Poor muscle tone, especially of the neck muscles
A lack of head control when baby is pulled from a lying to a sitting position
One or more painful, red spots or bumps that develops into an open ulcer
White or yellow center sores on the inner surface of the cheeks and lips, tongue, upper surface of the mouth, and the base of the gums
Small size (most often under one third inch or 1 centimeter across) sores on the inner surface of the cheeks and lips, tongue, upper surface of the mouth, and the base of the gums
Gray color as healing starts on the sores developed on the inner surface of the cheeks and lips, tongue, upper surface of the mouth, and the base of the gums
Flushing (face, neck, or upper chest), or widened blood vessels seen on the skin (telangiectasias)
Heart problems, such as leaking heart valves, slow heartbeat, low or high blood pressure
Clumsiness of the hand when gripping objects
Numbness or tingling or tingling in the thumb and next two or three fingers of one or both hands
Numbness or tingling of the palm of the hand
Pain that extends to the elbow
Pain in the wrist or hand in one or both hands
Problems with fine finger movements (coordination) in one or both hands
Wasting away of the muscle under the thumb (in advanced or long-term cases)
Weakness in one or both hands
Cloudy, fuzzy, foggy, or filmy vision
Difficulty seeing at night or in dim light
Problems seeing shapes against a background or the difference between shades of colors
Frequent and strong urge to urinate
Pressure, pain, or spasms in your back or the lower part of your belly
Bulging eyeball, usually on one side of face
Cannot move the eye in a particular direction
Decreased appetite (may also be increased or unchanged)
Diarrhea, either constant or off and on
Lactose intolerance (common when the person is diagnosed, often goes away after treatment)
Stools that are foul smelling, oily, or stick to the toilet when flushed
Pain or tenderness in the affected area
Skin redness or inflammation that gets bigger as the infection spreads
Skin sore or rash that starts suddenly, and grows quickly in the first 24 hours
Tight, glossy, stretched appearance of the skin
Warm skin in the area of redness
Muscle aches and joint stiffness from swelling of the tissue over the joint
Dim and blurred blind spot in the center of vision
Distortion of straight lines with the affected eye
Objects appearing smaller or farther away with the affected eye
Nervous system changes that may start suddenly, including confusion, delirium, double vision, decreased vision, sensation changes, speech problems, weakness, or paralysis
Weakness or unusual sensations that come and go, and involve smaller areas
Headache in one or more parts of the head, may seem like a migraine
Numbness in an area of the body
Abnormal vaginal bleeding between periods, after intercourse, or after menopause
Vaginal discharge that does not stop, and may be pale, watery, pink, brown, bloody, or foul-smelling
Periods that become heavier and last longer than usual
Vaginal bleeding after douching or intercourse
Neck stiffness that gets worse over time
Numbness or abnormal sensations in the shoulders or arms
Headaches, especially in the back of the head
Pain on the inside of the shoulder blade and shoulder pain
Unusual vaginal discharge that does not go away: discharge may be gray, white or yellow in color
Pressure or heaviness in the pelvis
Increased infections in the lungs, skin, and mucous membranes

The blisters are most often first seen on the face, middle of the body, or scalp, after a day or two, the blisters become cloudy and then scab, meanwhile, new blisters form in groups, they often appear in the mouth, in the vagina, and on the eyelids
Discharge from the penis or rectum
Tenderness or pain in the testicles
Symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), salpingitis (inflammation of the fallopian tubes), or liver inflammation similar to hepatitis
Pain in the upper right abdomen that may radiate to the back
Pain on the upper right side or upper middle part of the abdomen, it may also be felt in the back or below the right shoulder blade, the pain may come and go and feel sharp, cramp-like, or dull
Pain in the right upper or middle upper abdomen for at least 30 minutes,the pain may be constant and intense, it can be mild or severe
Pain in the right upper part of the abdomen
Sharp, cramping, or dull pain in upper right or upper middle of your belly lasting for 30 minutes
Problems walking due to weakness or lack of feeling in the feet
Trouble using the arms and hands or legs and feet due to weakness
Sensation changes, such as numbness or decreased sensation, pain, burning, tingling, or other abnormal sensations (usually affects the feet first, then the arms and hands)
Enlarged lymph nodes, liver, or spleen
Infections that keep coming back (recur), despite treatment
Quick movements of the arms, legs, or other areas
Sounds (grunts, throat clearing, contractions of the abdomen or diaphragm)
Pressure under the lower left ribs from a swollen spleen
Abdominal pain may last from hours to days; over time, may always be present
Abdominal pain may get worse from eating
Abdominal pain may get worse from drinking alcohol
Chronic weight loss, even when eating habits and amounts are normal
Weakness or numbness of arms, legs, face
Enlarged neck or presence of goiter, which may be the only early symptom
Small or shrunken thyroid gland (late in the disease)
Abdominal pain due to pancreatitis (inflammation of the pancreas)
Symptoms of nerve damage, such as loss of feeling in the feet or legs, and memory loss
Yellow deposits of fatty material in the skin called xanthomas, these growths may appear on the back, buttocks, soles of the feet, or ankles, knees and elbows
Small, red spider-like blood vessels on the skin
Fluid buildup in the legs (edema) and in the abdomen (ascites)
Redness on the palms of the hands
In men, impotence, shrinking of the testicles, and breast swelling
Easy bruising and abnormal bleeding, most often from swollen veins in the digestive tract
Bleeding from upper or lower gastrointestinal tract
Ability to touch shoulders together in front of body
Increased risk of getting flat foot, abnormal curvature of spine (scoliosis) and knee deformities
High risk of hearing loss due to infections
Increased risk of fracture due to decreased bone density
Constant urge to have a bowel movement
Sharp chest or shoulder pain, made worse by a deep breath or a cough
Feeling weak all over and muscle aches
Headache behind the eyes (typically during fever)
Abdominal pain and tenderness in the lower abdomen
Decreased sensation, numbness, or tingling in the top of the foot or the outer part of the upper or lower leg
Foot that drops (unable to hold the foot up)
"Slapping" gait (walking pattern in which each step makes a slapping noise)
Weakness of the ankles or feet
Loss of muscle mass because the nerves aren't stimulating the muscles
Pain that is much higher than expected with the injury
Severe pain that doesn't go away after taking pain medicine or raising the affected area
Decreased sensation, numbness, tingling, weakness of the affected area
Changes in skin temperature, switching between warm or cold
Faster growth of nails and hair
Severe burning, aching pain that worsens with the slightest touch or breeze
Skin that slowly becomes blotchy, purple, pale, or red; thin and shiny; swollen; more sweaty
Acting somewhat confused, feeling unable to concentrate, or not thinking clearly
Being drowsy, hard to wake up, or similar changes
Memory loss (amnesia) of events before the injury or right after
Feeling like you have lost time
Cruel or aggressive behavior toward people or animals (for example: bullying, fighting, using dangerous weapons, forcing sexual activity, and stealing)
Not going to school (truancy, beginning before age 13)
Lying to get a favor or avoid things they have to do
An infant does not seem to be visually aware of the world around them (if cataracts are in both eyes)
Gray or white cloudiness of the pupil (which is normally black)
The red eye glow (red reflex) of the pupil is missing in photos, or is different between the 2 eyes
Bleeding from the umbilical cord just after birth
Heavy bleeding after injury or surgery
Nosebleeds that do not stop easily
Crusts that form on the eyelid overnight (most often caused by bacteria)
Enlarged pupil that does not get smaller when a light shines on it
Increasing pressure on the brain, usually from hydrocephalus
Disrupting hormone production by the pituitary gland
Pressure or damage to the optic nerve
Dementia that gets worse quickly over a few weeks or months
Feeling that you need to pass stools, even though your bowels are already empty (tenesmus), it may involve straining, pain, and cramping
Watery diarrhea, which may be blood
A bend in the penis, which most often begins at the area where you feel the scar tissue or hardening
Softening of the portion of the penis beyond the area of scar tissue
Problems with penetration or pain during intercourse
Pressure or cramping in the lower middle abdomen or back
Strong need to urinate often, even right after the bladder has been emptied
Enlarged lymph nodes, especially in the neck
Skin that feels warm to the touch
Changes in alertness (usually more alert in the morning, less alert at night)
Decrease in short-term memory and recall
Disorganized thinking, such as talking in a way that doesn't make sense
Emotional or personality changes, such as anger, agitation, depression, irritability, and overly happy
Movements triggered by changes in the nervous system
Deep sleep that lasts for a day or longer
Difficulty doing more than one task at a time
Difficulty solving problems or making decisions
Forgetting names of familiar people, recent events, or conversations
Taking longer to do more difficult mental activities
Personality changes and loss of social skills, which can lead to inappropriate behaviors
Losing interest in things previously enjoyed, flat mood
Becoming easily hurt by criticism or disapproval
Becoming overly focused on fears of being abandoned
Feeling very upset or helpless when relationships end
Having difficulty making decisions without support from others
Having problems expressing disagreements with others
